Dutches of suffolke.

div.p: THE LIFE OF THE DVTCHESS OF SVFFOLKE.
As it hath beene divers and sundry times acted, with good applause.
Imprinted by A. M. for Jasper Emery; at Flowerdeluce in Paules Church-yard. 1631.

div.head: Actus Primus.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: KNights, Gentlemen, and Yeomen,
attend her Graces seruice; sheele abroad.

div.stage: Enter Cranwell vshering the Dutches of Suffolke, a gentlewoman bearing vp her trayne, Bertie, and gentlemen. at the other doore Begger

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Be vncoverd Gentelmen.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Rome there, backe Beggers.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Bertie, deale mine Almes.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Pray for the Dutches, friends.

sp.speaker: Beg.
sp.l: Heavens preserue your Grace.

div.stage: Enter one with a Letter, delivers it kneeling.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: What saiest thou? from my King? I kisse his lines,
As humbly as my infant penitence,
When due correction threatned mine offence:
I may intreat the Palatine with grace,
All curtesie and favours, for my Soveraignes sake,
I will present him with smooth countenance,
But for the poynt heere touching Marriage,
Beseech my Prince of pardon, since, as yet,
My Widdowes teares are scarce wipt from my cheeke,
Touching the businesse, boute Sir Roger Willowbie,
My deere neere kinseman, Ile not returne
You empty handed backe, but send
His highnesse Parram Lordship to dispose,
And thanke his gratious providence for him.
Returne my salutations on my knee,
And say my whole possessions are all his,
Berty reward his paines, On;
sp.stage: Enter Gardner to the Tower guarded.
sp.l: Stay, and know the reason of that guard,
How? giue mine eyes the fulnesse of their wish,
Skreene not my Ioyes, I pray stand all aside,
My Gossip Gardner led vnto the Tower,
Tis pitty, nay man leaue your curtesie,
My passion has no teares to answer you,
Truth now I hope hath got a holliday,
The tyrant Wolfe in hould, the Lambes may play,
Forward to Sussex house in Barnisby street:
More obiects yet of comfort? what is he?

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Bonner commanded to the Martialsie.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Fagots will then grow cheape, they say, my Lord,
That you haue bought vp all our fire-wood,
To send vs in a shining flame to heauen,
But Bertie, see how leane has studdy made him,
And his care with sweating in represse of errors,
An Ell will hardly girdle his leane wast.
Sands, Ile defer your welcome yet from Cambridge,
To shew you heere a president of zeale.

sp.speaker: Bonn.
sp.l: Madam these scornes liue not with charity,
My conscience is content to beare this crosse.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: And mine as well content that thou should'st beare it,
think'st thou I will disburthen thy content,
Good man thou art deceiv'd, my charity
Shuts vp the doores against thy misery,
I tell thee, all my sorrowes are dried vp,
With this sweete breath of comfort, to see thee,
Infranchise truth by thy captivity.

sp.speaker: Bonn.
sp.l: Time flaters you awhile, heaven has a power,
Can change the White to Sable in an houre,
My welthier thoughts, yet tell me I shall liue,
these scornes to quittance, your free heart to greeue,
For time is rich in ransome, she may rayse,
Exit wit● gard●●▪ the scorn'd and captiv'd Bonner, ware those dayes.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: If Englands sinne deserues that curse againe,
Doubtlesse my life the truth should still maintaine.

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.l: The grace of heaven make strong that your resolue.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Tut Sands, I am no novice to beare off
The gusty shocke of danger, heere is proofe,
Hath bid the Cannon of rough threatning griefe,
The deaths of one deere Husband, and two Sonnes,
(Regenerate in the fame of their deserts.)
Haue made a violent shot against this brest,
But by the manly courage of that ioy,
Is knit vnto my spirits, to behold
The exild truth, now soiourning with time,
The rage of their repugnancie recoyles,
And I am Mistris of a Virgin heart.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: With pardon gratious Madam,
Could Berties rude perswasion please your eares,
I wish it cloth'd with Hymens royalties:
A husband, like an Ammell, would inrich
Your golden vertues.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: How Men can praise themselues.
Mariage is good, but wheres the husband good?
A loving husband, Bertie, true in touch
May sweare, so they wilbe, few proue such.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Durst my opinion venture, but to speake him,
I could commend that merit to your heart,
As I presume, your fancie would imbrace.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Void all the Chamber, Bertie, but your selfe,
The husband now, come man, feare not to speake,
You haue absolution, ere you doe begin,
The husband can report his true deserts.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: As much as observations greedy eye,
Could well retayne, keepes warme vpon my tongue,
Which to your noblest consideration was in honors wombe,
And from her suckt his Nutriment of life,
His spirit like an ensigne doth display
The worthinesse of his heroicke birth,
His more concealed vertues varnish that,
To make his Comet (merit,) wondred at,
Nature in moulding of his lyneaments,
Has sham'd the cunning workemanship of Arte,
That he is Madam, as your wish would make,
The richer in desert for your worthes sake.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: You haue describ'd the substance of a man,
Such as might ravish the most chastest thoughts,
Virginity could sinne in wish of him,
For but on my deceased Brandons breath,
Did never waite such rich perfections,
In them I shall but re-espouse mine owne,
Marry one Husband twice, embrace the dead,
Hug in mine armes a Suffolke buried.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: If honorable Loue liue in a man,
It guides the vertues of the Palatine.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: The Palatine? has he your wishes voyce.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Could it assure him of your fancies choyce.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: His stately honors are vnmatcht for mine.

sp.speaker: Berty.
sp.l: His greatnesse reflects beames into your shine.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: That greatnesse claymes a duty from my heart.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: No more then his loue offers your desert.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Your humble eyes see's merit, his will not,
Our weaker worthes in Marriage are forgot.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Nay rather Madam Wedlock doth inroule,
The speciall essence of your rare deserts,
Remembring your perfections.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I, they could liue in your humility,
And my affections best afford them thee,
Whilst thy sweete tongue solicites for thy friend,
Into thy bosome all my thoughts I send.
Cranwell what newes.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: The County Pallatine, now king of Poland.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: King of Poland?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Madam survey your thoughts,
Master your feares, and crowne your happinesse,

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: King of Poland?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: You Queene my hopes would see.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Queene of my rich desires in marrying thee,
What of this king of Poland?

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: He staies your graces leisure,
Accompanied with the Earle of Arundell.

div.stage: Enter the Palatine being King of Poland, and Arundell.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Intreat their presence,
Welcome royall Prince,
My noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Palat.
sp.l: Madam, my latest service comes to bring
An old affection from a new made king.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: My Pristine gratulations thus accept
The humble proffer of your soueraigne heart:
But let me tell you, my thrice gratious Lord,
You deale not Kingly, by advantag'd meanes
To set vpon my infancy of Loue,
To ambush lay it by intelligence:
You know my meaning, theres a privie theefe
I know you set to pillage my affections,
He durst not else haue broke my secrets vp.
His travell has not loytered in your sute,
Nor will I be vngratefull to his paines.
The Duke Northumberland, with the Earle of Erbaigh,
Desire to haue accesse vnto your grace.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: More sutors? well, they are all welcome; vsher them in.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: Health and faire fortune
Waite on Suffolks Dutches.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Your wishes returne their vertues on your selfe.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: The king salutes you in my vassall breath,
And bad me tell you, he received your gift
With thankefull welcome, and bestowed the same
(Peec'd out with honor, from his noble bounty)
Vpon your cosen Sir Roger Willowby,
Creating him Lord Willowby of Parram,
To build remembrance of your gracious gift:
Further he praies you to intreat this Prince,
The Earle of Erbaigh with faire curtesie.

sp.speaker: Erba.
sp.l: Madam, the loue of your perfections
Hath call'd me hither, and of them I craue,
A welcome to my loyalty of heart.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I wish sir, my perfections of that wealth
To rate so high a merit as yours is:
But Princes, leaue this cheapning of my loue,
It is a bad thing deere.
Shall I beseech of you my Lord of Poland, and the rest,
Princes or whosoever tenders me
The humble service of his noble heart
As to digest my choyce with patience:
Amongst you I will choose, and at this time
And in his like interre my widdowhood,
Amongst a throng of merits one but enters,
One wins the Goale still, though a thousand venters,
This man must but possesse me, let the voyce
Of my affections, please all with her choyce.

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.l: Pleas'd or displeas'd, you women choose your liking,
And reason you should haue it, or als one
Youle take a fall to haue it; fancies force
Makes honest plainnesse often speed the worse,
Choose Madam choose, and please thine owne content.

sp.speaker: Berty.
sp.l: The king of Poland Madam.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: How this fellow
Wakes my remembrance for the king of Poland,
As though my fancy hung vpon his tongue,
I never shot a blunted arrow foorth,
Nor shall my choyce recoyle vpon his worth,
Whom Ile call mine; come worst of fate,
Berty I choose thy selfe my marriage mate,
Vpon this low foundation I erect
The Pallace of mine honors, on this knee
I place the head of mine authority;
Let hand from hand exchange their offices,
Whats mine is thine, thine mine, seal'd with this kisse.

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.l: How madcap Dutches; what and ioyne lips to?
What ere we thought, I see it is a match.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: You see blind fancies follie in my choyce,
His worth prevailes, nor will I change my voyce.

sp.speaker: Berty.
sp.l: By the deere loyalty my thoughts doe owe
To this vnmeasur'd grace you heape on me,
And by the vertue of a Christian faith,
The rellish of this blessing is so strong,
That when I leaue to loue, I liue too long.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Princes, let your displeasure chide his merit,
Which stole my loue your honors would inherit.

sp.speaker: Palat.
sp.l: My fury thus bursts forth, to wish increase
Of your spouse vertues in your liues sweete peace.

sp.speaker: Erba.
sp.l: My hatred dies not so, but I would see
Your merits liue in your posteritie.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Whereat frowne you sir?

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: I hope it is no breach of duty, to conceale
Our close affections, they are priviledg'd,
And I will keepe them so, you haue my seruice;
If it may pleasure, so; if not, I care not:
Ile mourne mine owne sinnes,
Take your Cloke and spare not.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: If you be tired with the wearing it,
Good speed you, Ile not breake you backe with care.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: You haue my heart, whil'st I an honest asse,
(For so I count all men of patience,)
Haue laden it with whole loades of businesses,
With iaunting on your errands, drudgt at home,
With so strong diligence, that sleepe could scarce
Approch my eye-lids for a sennights space:
The honor of your Celler liues in me,
You scarce command a throat can gulpe a health,
You thinke I flatter, take good fellowes words,
And him whose merit claymes preheminence,
By their opinion, deale your recompence.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: If you meane me, I will not canvase
With you for the voyce of quaint opinion;
Youle waye downe the scales,
Her honorable loue, the gift of fate,
Not due of merrit, doth advance my state.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Why sir, might she not bestow her loue on me?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: She might.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: She might, more foole she did not, but al's one
All friends now, heeres my hand, my spleenes downe.

sp.speaker: Bert,
sp.l: In this imbrace I send a generall loue,
To all my fellow servitors:
I know some lowres vpon my happinesse,
How vndeserued, let my offices
Of loue to you, and duty to her grace,
In their impartiall verdit render vp.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: O, take my answere as the generall voyce,
For from my mouth breathes their opinions:
She lessens not her honours in your choyce,
But makes you Lord of her affections,
And them we serue not, but her royalties,
Which, as they are not lessened, why should we
Shrinke from their seruice; whom her loue doth honor,
May challenge from vs speciall reverence,
And so shall you, as homage for that loue,
Whose soverainty commands our services.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: Consent I see is liberall to this match,
And offers franckly my applauding heart,
Wishing of heauen to smile vpon your loues,
That from them may grow vp such gallant spirits
As may renowne this land with honor'd merits.

sp.speaker: Bonn.
sp.l: Good morrow to my Lord of Winchester;
How doe you like our ayre i'th Marshalseas,
From that ith Tower? welcome toot my Lord.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Oh I thanke your loue,
But had we once our liberties,
We would set night vpon these morning skies.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Oh that that houre were come, the king once dead.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Whats that my Lord of London?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: I, pray man, pray, that heaven would take
Our good king Edward to yon happy land,
Hee's sicke, hee's sicke, heaven take the infant child:
For this crack'd world his vertues are too milde:
Is not this charitable, what sayst thou man?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: But is the king sicke?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: And princes Mary well,
Oh how I long to heare his passing bell.
Soft who comes heere.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Health to my honour'd Lords.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: That were, thou meanest.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: That are, I bring your Lordships from our anointed Queene.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Queene? is Edward dead?

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: King Edward, of that name the sixt, is dead, and

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Who, who I beseech thee, guides the state?

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: She that repeales you to your former seats,
Royall Queene Mary.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: See.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Good hold my backe, this suddaine blast of comfort
Blowes me vp, where is my rivall Ridley and the rest,
They now shall fire for this.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Sent downe to Oxford.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Thence they shall not stirre,
Till fire consume them, if I be Winchester.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: By me her highnesse greetes you with that sea,
Adding vnto it, high Chancellor of England.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: An office good my Lord may coyne revenge
With Iustice stampe to pay our enemies.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: My Lord of London, thats your title now,
Restor'd vnto it with her graces favor.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: And if affection lenifie my duty,
Let me respectlesse die without her favor.

sp.speaker: Paget.
sp.l: Where be the Lords of Winchester & London?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: The good Lord Paget, welcome, pray, what newes sir?

sp.speaker: Paget.
sp.l: Her highnesse giues vs ioynt commission
By vertue of this Patent to peruse,
And clense the state of impious sectaries,
Wherewith it was infected in the dayes
Of her deceased brother Edwards raigne,

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Without affection of affinity.

sp.speaker: Paget.
sp.l: Of any, not her sister is except.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Then let our Suffolkes Dowager expect
Answere for her scorn'd taunts, she threw on me of late
That hot spirit, fire and flax, Madam fagot stick,
If she recant not I will fagot her,
If all the wood in Middlesex can doo t,
Or Londons Bishopricke haue meanes to pay fort
Ile not niggard her bones and I doe, arayne my charity.

sp.speaker: Paget.
sp.l: I haue already sent Processe for her husband,
Forth by Clunie.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: My man, a trustie fellow
Worthy imployment in the Lollards tower,
But heere comes Bartie, welcome honest Clunie
It was well done, an honest knaue, Ile gratifie thy loue
As I will quittance such malignant hates.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: As whose, ant please your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: A vengeance flatter you,
Your curteous eare, weares daggers in your heart.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My eare, my Lord, is servant to my heart.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: They serue indeed to guide the envious heart.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Sure I thinke Bertie be an honest man,
Religious was his education,
With our deceased Chancelor whom he served,
If since his Lady haue not wean'd him from it.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Your honor still shall find me the same man.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: In substance, but how in Religion?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: As then a member of the selfe same Church.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: My good Lady your Wife sir, shees not so.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I doe beseech your Lordships to suspend
And smother your opinions till a triall
Blow vp the embers to an open flame,
Then censure as you find, and giue's your doome.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: If we but finde her answers halfe so calme.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Yes as thunder, she calme? as a baited Beare,
I will oppose my disputation,
Against a Colledge of best discipline,
Rather then with her braines, she sticks her iests▪
Like poysoned arrowes, in our tender spleenes:
Thinking the sanctuary of her high birth
To priviledge her fond presumption,

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: My credit sir be pawnd.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Your credit tut tut, she hangs vpon the mercy of the Queene,
But it will cast off her opinion.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Should she be cold, my Lords, or set a frowne
Vpon the alteration of her faith,
Your Lordships know the somes of money due,
From Charles the Emperour to her in the right,
Of her departed husband, Suffolkes Duke,
Which if your honorable licence would
Assigne me a free passage to those parts
To gather vp your vnexpected loue,
Would heate her good opinion with the zeale.
Where now the strangenes makes her somewhat stagger.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Let him goe my Lords, you shal go speed him hence
The way is broader vnto our reuenge,
Which I haue sworne to take vpon that Dame,
Whose scornefull taunts did so depraue my fame.
What saies my good Chancelor to this sute.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: You haue free passage Bertie, when you please.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: To scape your envies, if we crosse the seas.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Follow him Clunie and when thou thinkest,
The solemne farewell of divorced lips,
Hath part this husband from his honor'd wife,
With some especiall servants of the Queene
Enter the Dutches house in Barbican,
Take a true inventory of all her goods,
Discharge her household, saue a man or two.
One Woman, and the Nurse that suckles her Child,
And say you haue commandement from the Queene
To stay there till her highnesse further pleasure,
That she shall walke the hie-way to the Tower,
Be gon, performe thine Office carefully,
And I will pay thy paines as liberally.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: I goe my Lord, but doe you heare the newes?
How Docter Sands is scapt from the kings bench, and fled.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Send foorth our warrants into every Coast.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Towards Kent, towards Kent, post Clunie, run villaine
How starest thou? packe.
Liue in my bosome if thou bring him backe,
This Sands is Chaplaine to yon scornefull Dutches,
And he has tayne this lesson from her braynes,
That house of slie deuises, shees all wit,
Nor shall I sleepe vntill I ruine it.

div.head: Actus Secundus.

sp.speaker: Bertie.
sp.l: Madam, my promise of your penitence,
Wayed with the puissance of your high birth,
Wherein you are alied vnto the Queene,
Calmed the rough Menace of stout Gardner,
And set a reverence on sterne Bonners tongue,
Humbly to wish your reformation.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: The Queene is neere and deere vnto my blood,
In the remembrance of our mothers loues,
Which chargeth greater sorrow at my heart,
Then the huge shocke of their malignant threats;
My soule hath lodg'd the Trueth, it shall not thence,
Whil'st this weake flesh displayes her ayrie sence.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: But Madam, let your wisedome shut her vp,
Commit her not vnto your state to guard,
But humble your hie spirit, sleike your speech,
That envy may not stumble at mistrust,
Or find a rub to start suspition:
Weare a smoth brow in presence of your foes,
Be shaken with their threats, retreat your spirit,
Till they insult vpon your patience:
The Conquest won in your submission,
They slake the eager pursute of revenge,
To giue you time to purvey for your scape;
You know my leaue of passage ore the seas,
And with what cunning I haue color'd it,
To free my conscience from the gaile of feare.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: But still leaue mine vpon the rocke of care.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I goe to seeke releasement of that care,
Freely to spread the ensigne of your Faith:
A simple, rusticke home of liberty,
Is worth your honors in captivity.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: It is, it is, and would befit our hues,
To weare them out in contemplation:
There should we reade, vpon the naked walls,
The first creation of our wretchednesse;
There no intruding obiects of gaie clothes,
Imbrodered hangings, or rich tapistrie,
Shall wound the seruice which we owe to heaven.
Oh M. Bertie, there my wish would be;
Change honor'd woe for poore felicity.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ile lay a Barke at Leigh shall stay for you,
To be transported to me at Midelborow.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: But who conducts me to that Barke at Leigh?
Feare is a trusty guide, it is, it is,
Shee that knowes no way, that way will not misse,
I prethee goe, my Conscience to set free,
My tender feet shall learne to follow thee.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I goe.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Yet stay, nay goe, alas which way?
And must we part?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: We must,
My bodie's heere, thou hast my heart along with thee
Make much o'nt prethee, till we meete againe,
My body and my soule you both retayne.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Slip not my duty, I beseech your loue,
To her for whom my sorrowes shed more teares,
Then is my wounded Conscience charg'd with feares.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Patience, good Madam.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Passion Master Bertie,
My spleene is wounded with compassionate pitty,
I could drop out my Liver, rob my life
Of her deere essence, with immoderate sighes,
For that sweete Princes, wrong'd Elizabeth;
Now in the gripe of their pernitious hate,
A guard of Angels ring her life about,
From the malitious practise of her foes;
Rebate their furies, crosse their treacherous wayes,
Let truth in her outliue these bloody dayes.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Amen, amen, what shall I deliver to her from your grace?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: A comfortable salutation
To that heart sorrowing Lady which my prayer
From heaven has carried to her heart before.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Will you ought else?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: A kind embrace from you, exchange a teare, two,
And so farewell.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Oh this doth clog me more, waies downe my speed
Should beare our fortunes to a soft repose,
Not daring heere to peepe out of our thoughts,
Without the danger of the Vulters gripe,
Whose watching eyes of inquisition
Steales covertly vpon our purposes,
And yet you lag me with your loade of greefes.
I could tosse woe for woe vntill to morrow,
But then weede wake the wolfe with bleating sorrow.
With what vnwillingnesse I part from you
Let that and these receiu'd.
Adew, adew.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Now Cranwell, what would'st thou? thy M. gone.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: I am glad he stayed not, to peece out our money

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What heavy thoght straines moisture from thy heart

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: To see your greatnesse strucke with enuies dart.
Her highnesse servants haue attacht your goods,
Discharging all your household officers.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What remedy? this was my expectation: I was arm'd
With compleat resolution, to abide
The rigorous wrastle of this streame-borne tyde.
Faintst thou at this? then thou wouldst swoune to see
My honourd state changed to ragg'd misery.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: I will not line to see that.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Then thy loue is tried:
I thought it would haue lackied by my side.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: How meane you Madam?
When it tires in service of your Grace,
May I ne're more haue being on the earth,
Were you to passe th'extreamest of all woe,
Might I be worthy, I would share with you.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Vpon thy trust, then I repose my life,
Provide me 'gainst this even a Citizens Gowne,
Ath meanest fashion, like my present fortunes:
This night Ile hazzard to escape from hence,
Putting my feares into the hand of fate,
To trample on or readvance my state,
Wilt thou about it?

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: With a winged speed:
To cure your sorrowes this manly heart shall bleed.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Madam this world is changed.

sp.speaker: Dutch:
sp.l: Change thou with it.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Change, and I did it were no heresie:
These humors graple with my honesty,
But they are franticke fits, I let them passe.

sp.speaker: Dutch:
sp.l: Sir what are you?

sp.speaker: Clu:
sp.l: My name is Clunie, and now your graces keeper.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I heare you haue discharged my houshould Servants.

sp.speaker: Clu:
sp.l: It is her highnesse pleasure.

sp.speaker: Dut:
sp.l: Or Bonners hate, but I accept it with a thankfulnes.

sp.speaker: Clu:
sp.l: All are not yet discharged, but your choice
May call two men, a woman, and a Nurse.

sp.speaker: Dutch:
sp.l: Nay, Cranwell is all I will beseech of you.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Why Cranwell, more then Fox?

sp.speaker: Dutch:
sp.l: Because more staid, with him,
Because of most continuance,
And longest wearing in my services.

sp.speaker: Fox:
sp.l: What meane you by this wearing? I am sure,
My wits are worne as thinne as a Paper-leafe:
But tis the fairest end of Serving-men,
When we haue spent the pleasure of our youth,
Ene sweate it out with painefull industry,
To haue such itching slaues to eate vs out,
Doe you so light respect me? I as light
Will make of you, and it come within my power.

sp.speaker: Dutch:
sp.l: Farwell, pull downe thy stubbornesse of spirit:
There breathes no servant of more honesty:
wilt please your kindnesse, keeper, vsher me,
To teach my steps to vsher misery.

sp.speaker: Fox:
sp.l: Now Thomas?
What will you doe now, Thomas?
Your Mistres has discharged you, and your coate, Thomas,
Which was as deere to you, as your skin, Thomas,
It is puld over your eares, what remedy:
Has Fox nere a hole to hide's head in these extremities
Now I remember my Cozen Raynauld liues not far hence,
To him Ile make repayre, and feede on countrey poultrey
For a while, till I can cry Vindicta on this Dutches.
Well what Ile doe my thoughts not yet aprooue,
Fox will prooue true to trust, not false to loue,

div.stage: Enter Hughe Tiler, and Ienkin going to worke with a tray of Tiles and a Ladder.

sp.speaker: Til.
sp.l: Ienkin where art thou, harke what a kenell of hounds
Giues vs our welcome into kent, set vp, come & to this gere
Stampe the frost out of thy feete into the morter for me,
Ile catch me a heate or Ile beare it out at'h stones.

div.stage: Beats his fingers against his sides.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: A good fire would doe better with the fingers ends.

sp.speaker: Tiler.
sp.l: But a pot of Ale and a tost would doe best of all
With a cold stomack, over goe to the Cocke
And see if he came a'th kind, if his ale will
Make a man crow, weele leaue our implements heere
They will not runne away, and heeres no great croud
Of People ith towne, but if they be stolne, we may find 'em
Come Ienken, nimbly and stay by't.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: Whither now wilt thou dispose thy selfe
From the enraged pursuite of this search
That with their fresh breathings haue oft tired thee,
After so many hazards, whence my care
Has sweat in water to redeeme my feare,
Must I at last be forc't to yeild and die
Oh griefe, but who can slip his destenie
They come and I am tired,
Thankes heaven I haue found a meanes
I hope to shelter me in these extreames.

div.stage: Goeth vp the Ladder and workes.

sp.speaker: Clunie.
sp.l: Follow, pursue with swiftnesse and hees ours,
Soft heeres a Tiler, weele enquire of him
Which way he tooke, sirra you Tiler ho
Durtdauber with a vengeance answere me,
leaue singing of your necke verse, Rogue your best
Lest it prooue so indeed, youle answerer'
Tiler hoe.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: Say you sir, say you.

sp.speaker: Clunie.
sp.l: Say you goodman rascall?
Saw you not a man passe this way
With a speedy course but now.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: He crost downe that way.

sp.speaker: Clunie.
sp.l: How the devill did we misse him?
Tir'd I hold my life, and tayne some barne,
Or privy shead; come lets backe, search every nooke,
Ransacke the bushes, in each corner looke.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: How strong my spirit is to call them backe,
Arm'd with the steeled proofe of inocence,
That can rebate the edge of tyrany,
Invulnerable innocence she would goe,
But yet this flesh is frayle and full of feares,
To keepe the soule from yon Celestiall spheares,
Thy will be done my maker, whose great hand
Hath now my life from scortching malice fann'd.

sp.speaker: Ienkes,
sp.l: Come away Hugh ti ti tiler,
Now we haue lin'd our backs,
And warmd our bellies,
Lets doe our dayes worke in an houre
And drinke our selues drunke all the day after.

sp.speaker: Til.
sp.l: Whope, why the Cocke ale has spurd thee already.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Thou art a Coxcombe to say so, I will run vp, and Come downe my Ladder as nimble as a Squerrill.

sp.speaker: Tiler,
sp.p: For going vp I know not, but thou't come downe With thy head forward.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Why then that's a tricke more then ever thou sawest in thy life, oh in my ale I can doe any thing, tumble like an Eliphant.

sp.speaker: Clunie.
sp.l: Now where's this Tiler.

sp.speaker: Ienkin.
sp.l: At hand quoth pickepurse,

div.l: Ha you any worke for a tiler.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Not so much worke sir as you haue made for the searcher.
And which way crost the man?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: Should there not be two hundred of slates, saist thou?

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Answere me hobbihorse,
Which way crost he you saw enow?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: Who doe you speake to sir,
We haue forgot the hobbihorse.

sp.speaker: Tiler.
sp.l: Yes truely sir,
Looke well amongst your selues for him.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: The man, the man sirra Saunders, that you said you saw.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: That I saw said you, all that I saw was a russet
Gentleman with a tosted Cullizance, and hee went downe
Gutter-lane I assure you.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: That's as true as Sands crost this way, and wee not see him.

sp.speaker: Tiler.
sp.p: Did he crosse this way and you not see him, the more blind buzzard you.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.p: You told vs sirra enow, he went this way.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Who I, then I told you a lye, for I was then sipping my morning draught.

sp.speaker: Clu
sp.l: Say fellowes did not he direct vs thither.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: I, who I? Ienken the Tiler.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: I you.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Blesse my slating, is the devill amongst you, that you fall so fast a lying, if I saw any of you before would every slate I haue were in your bellies, why doe you not know Ienken the Tiler.

sp.speaker: Tiler.
sp.l: Nor hugh the good Dutches of Suffolkes man.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: The Dutches man, an Hereticke.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Nay nay, thats most certaine, whats an Erewig sir, a good fellow I hope.

sp.speaker: Clu,
sp.l: You shall haue that defind,
When you come before my Lord.

sp.speaker: Tiler,
sp.l: Oh by no meanes,
He spits nothing but fire and fagot-sticks.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: No matter, I haue ale enough in my belly to
Quench vm.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: So guard them safe, these villaines haue conveid
That traytor Sands their fellow, hence.

sp.speaker: Ienk.
sp.l: Not I, I desire you, I renounce and confound you.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Dam vp the brick bats mouth, convey them hence,
Tis they shall pay the price of Sands offence.

div.stage: Enter Dutches like a Citizens Wife with Cranwell.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Cranwell.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Speake softly, where is Nurse, speake softly prethee Lord, why loyters she, but call her not: soft, soft, what creaking shooes hast thou got Cranw. to betray our feares, put off them traytors.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Thou speakest too loud.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Neither my tongue, nor shoes, can reach an eare.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Yes Cranwell but they doe of iealous feare.
My life is on the hazard of this game
And I mistrust each step will cheate the same.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: O that the poyson of this feare were once removed.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: We should not then halt heere
The poyson hath the treason of my foes,
I wish but patience to abide their blowes,
But who comes heere, Nurse, with a candle light
Tis darkenesse woman must guide out our feere.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: What light is that there ho?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Nurse what hast thou done?
Disperse away, to Lyon key begon.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: What ho, will none speake there, awake the guard.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: What stay you for, for heavens sake will you goe,
Good Cranwell, sweet Nurse, linger not my woe.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: How will you find that way you yet nere went?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Ile 'trust in him that guides the Innocent,
Giue me my Child, & Mantle, now heavens pleasure:
Frewell, come life or death, Ile hug my treasure,
Nay chide not pretty babe, our enemies come
Thy crying will pronounce thy mothers dome.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Shees gone, shes gone.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Not far, but be thou still
This gate may shade vs from their envious will.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Gone, gone, pursue her or we are vndone.

sp.speaker: Dutch
sp.l: Oh feare what art thou! lend me wings to file,
Direct me in this plunge of misery,
Nature has taught the Child obedience,
Thou hast bin humble to thy mothers wish,
Oh let me kisse these dutious lips of thine,
That would not kill thy mother with a cry,
Now forward whither heaven directs, for I
Can guide no better then thine infancy,
Heere are two Pilgrims bound to Lyon-key,
And neither knowes one footstep of the way,
Returne you, then tis time to shift me hence.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Search euery corner, heere, behind this gate
Her mantle, oh the lucke, had we but staid
To search this nooke, when fury bore vs hence
With violence to overtake her course,
We had prevented her intended scape
But what heaven would not, could not, tis decreed,
Her innocent life, should not by envy bleed:
But heere we stint not, to pursue her flight,
I know twill boyle vp Bonners rancorous spight.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Thus far, but Heaven knowes where wee haue escapt
The eager pursuite of our enemies,
Having for guidance my attentiue feare,
Still I looke backe, still starte my tyred feet,
Which never till now measur'd London street,
My honors scornd that custome, they would ride,
Now forc't to walke, more weary paine to bide:
Thou shalt not doe so child, Ile carry thee
In sorrowes armes to welcome misery,
Custome must steele thy youth with pinching want,
That thy great birth, in age may beare with scant,
Sleepe peaceablie sweete ducke, and make no noise
Me thinkes each step is deaths aresting voice,
We shall meete Nurse anon, a dug will come
To please my quiet infant, when, Nurse, when?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Who's that calls Nurse?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Aye me I am oreheard.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Master Cranwell.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Who goes there? Nurse?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Cranwell.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Nurse:
sp.l: My sweete Lady.

sp.speaker: Dutc.
sp.l: Whist honest Nurse? how strangely are we met?

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: It is the place where you appointed vs.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Then heaven is gratious to my ignorance,
For had this night worne on the pride of day,
By I it could not haue found out the way.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Are you not weary Madam?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Admit I be, let patience ease all, theres no remedy:
Within cry. For Grauesend hoe.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Whats that, he frighted me.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: They call for their passengers to Graues-end.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Passe we our feares with them, there staies at Lee
A Barke that will redeeme our liberty,
If you dare venture, with my fortunes goe,
A tide of Ioy, may turne this streame of Woe.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: How you resolue of me, I know not, try,
And when I shrinke, brand me with infamy.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: In heavens name, on then, fellowes all in sorrow,
When we stand need, weele mutuall comfort borrow.

div.stage: Enter Bonner, Gardner, Clunie, Ienkin and Tiler, guarded.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: My Lord sit downe, stand foorth thou Ipocret.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: I never drunke Ippocrasse in my life sir,
Twas strong Ale that I am guilty of.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Clunie giue evidence against this wretch,
Hath set his hand to helpe a traytor hence.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: Indeed my Lord I am no Traytor, I am a Tilor,
sp.p: Clunie tells your Lordship a fable, we saw no such Man, not wee.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: No, wilt thou obstinately stand in it,
Didst not thou lend him a disguise, imploy him
Mongst other laborers about thy worke,
And yet wilt thou deny thou art no Traytor.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Slaue, Villaine, Dogge,
Haue we not heere the honest testimony
Of mine owne Parator, that saw him clothed
In thy apparell, and darest thou deny it,
Fagots, fagots, hence toth' stake with him.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: Oh good my Lord, I shall never indure it,
I was wance but burnt ith hand, and I haue bin
The worse fort ever since, doe but heere me,
Prooue that I had any other apparell this seven yeares,
Then that you see vpon my backe, and burne me not,
But cut me into rashers, and broyle me for Carbonadoes.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: My Lords as I am Clunie, and your Parator,
This counterfeit simplicitude was he,
That twixt the houres of 12. and 1. at Noone,
Convayed the impious Traytor from our search,
By shifting him into his homely raggs.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Twixt 12. and 1. nere trust me, but at that very time I and my fellow heere, (canst thou speake nothinge for thy selfe) were at dinner at mother Puttocks, with a piece of a Tripe and a blacke-Pudding, by the same token there was a candles end in't as long as my thumbe.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: So, so, yar a cunning Knaue, but sirra, sirra,
This cannot serue your turne, you rescued him,
And that by'th law is held as Capitall,
As if thy selfe wert guilty of the crime.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: His crime my Lord is it not manifest,
That hees a favourer of these Scismatikes,
And what is that but flat rebellion.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Goe too, he must frye fort, he, shall I say the word,
Bonner that ere long will purge this land with bonfiers,
We come not with the Oliue branch of Peace,
But with the sword of Iustice, these Hidraes-heads will still
Be florishing, vnlesse at once we giu't a fatall stroke,
Let them convert to ashes, let them burne,
So shall the State be quiet: how now, what newes?
What haue you caught the Dutches.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Most strangely sir, she did escape my hands,
Besides at Billinsgate haue I kept narrow search,
Yet for my life could set no eye on her.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: But we haue all this while taine a wrong course,
Shall we imagine being hunted thus:
She would commit the sauegard of her life
To common passage, where she was assurd
There would be diligent waight laid for her:
No, shees more subtile, all the world, my Lord,
Shall not perswade, but shees in England still,
In Marget, Lee, or some such bordering towne.

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: And in good time I met a man of hers,
One Fox, my Lord, a fellow, as it seemes,
Disgrac't by her, that told me we were wide
In that we went about.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Where met you him.

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: Comming from Algate.

sp.speaker: Bonn.
sp.l: Would he not confesse
Which way his Lady Mistrisse was escapt?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: With much a doe my Lords, with threats and promises,
At last he told me he would bring
Where we might trace her, and intrap her too.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Why brought you not that fellow to our presence?
He shall haue dispensation how he will,
So he be trusty, and performe his word.

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: He promis'd faithfully to meete me heere.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Well if he come, your eare.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Now Fox devise to qualifie
Thy nature to thy name,
These be meere Caniballs
That take no pleasure but in sucking blood,
And though vnluckly it was thy chance,
To fall into their hands, yet be not thou
( How ever outward grievances may vrge)
A traytor to thy Lady; smooth with these,
That vnder collour to betray the Dutches,
She may haue safer liberty to passe.

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: See my Lords, hee's come.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Come hither sirra, you did serue the Dutches,
And tis no doubt but you can giue vs notice
Which way shee's fled, stand no vpon nice tearmes
As fearing to incurre some deadly sinne,
But tell vs plainely which way she is gone.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: My Lords, I cannot readily discover
Which way shee's gone, by reason I haue bin
Long in disgrace, and quite dismist the house,
But sure it is, she went disguis'd from hence,
And tis not possible but she must lurke,
Within some Haven towne neere to the coast.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: What Towne, as thou imaginest?

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: My Lords I thinke toward Dover,
Or the Downes of Kent.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Nay thats not likely, soft, some
News I hope.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Health to this honorable presence,
I come to certifie your Lordships all,
That as we kept the Ports on Essex side,
Twas credibly reported, that the Dutches
With little or no trayne, is lodg'd in Lee,
And for she is disguis'd, and our Commission
Expir'd the date, we craue a fresh supply,
And some direction how to intercept her.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: No better meanes then to renew our warrant,
And send this fellow with it that doth know her,
Into what shape so ere she be transform'd.
It shall be so, I thanke thee Pursyvant
For thy good newes, it glads me at the heart,
I shall at length be even with this proud Dutches,
At Lee in Essex, oh tis excellent:
But I will tell you how't shall be my Lord,
Fox shall not goe alone, Clunie and I
Will beare him companie, and withall, ha, ha,
I cannot choose but laugh to tell the rest,
As shee's disguis'd to hide her from my flght,
So will I be, to take her, in her slight,
Is it not good, is it not rare my Lord,
Nay is it not the best that ere you heard,
When subtilty by fraud shall be debar'd,
I warrant you shee's ours Clunie, Fox come hither,
Provide you straight, Fox thou shalt goe with me,
Ha, wilt thou not.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: (A plague vpon you,) I must answer, I.
How ere my heart abhor this treachery,
My Lord I will.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Why now thou pleasest me,
And I will richly recompence thy paines,
But for we will not, our affaires at home,
In the meane time be slackt, or intermitted,
You my good Lords shall haue a speciall care
About it straight, Fox, Clunie, follow me,
This is to Bonner chiefe felicity.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Fox, and Ienken.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Yes, I will follow,
Though not further ye,
I trust this is a meanes ordain'd of Heaven,
To bridle this bloodsuckers cruelty,
But how now, what art thou.

sp.speaker: Ienken.
sp.p: Marry sir an honest man and a Tiler, that was sent for hither to bee examined about wan M. Sands, and it seemes for Ioy they haue to kno where the Dutches is, they haue forgotten me, what were I best to doe.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: What else but get thee home vnto thy house,
Away be packing, since they haue forgot thee,
Doe not thou tarry to reviue their memory.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: Nay if I put them in mind on't, let me be chokt,
For want of drinke, since Ale thou art so luckie,
Ile take the tother pot while it is nappy.

div.head: Actus Tertius.
div.stage: Enter Dutches, Cranwell, Nurse, the Child, Sands, Master Goseling a Merchant.

sp.speaker: Goseli.
sp.l: Most honourd Princes, thinke your selfe as safe,
In my protection at this towne of Lee,
As in the strongest hould you doe possesse.

sp.speaker: Dut:
sp.l: Good M. Goseling now we flie to you
As to our harbor, in your hands it lies,
Either to comfort, or confound our liues?

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: We now are chaced by many savage men,
That with blood-thirstinesse pursue our deaths,
Being yet within the closure of their armes,
And desperate of all hope to you we flie.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Cosen Goseling 'mongst a world of other men.
The providence of heaven chose out you,
Either to be made famous for true faith,
Or by disloyall dealing infamous,
Presuming on your perfit honesty,
I brought my noble mistresse, this graue Doctor,
This infant Lady, and present vs all,
To your safe conduct: o betray our liues,
Bonner will giue you gold, woe to that good
That bad men get, by selling guiltlesse blood,
If any such thought haue possest your heart,
Make Marchandise of mine, let these escape,
For these are pretious in the eyes of heaven,
Let them depart, leade me to Bonner first,
Happy my blood, to quench his raging thirst.

sp.speaker: Gosel.
sp.l: Cosen I wonder, what desert of mine
Hath bred in you this bad opinion,
But I impute it rather to the zeale
You beare your Ladies safety, then the thought
Of any treason you discerne in me,
Madam my life, yet out of dangers gripe,
I thrust into your perill, witnesse heaven,
I take vpon me to conceale your flight,
And now I am as deepe in Bonners hate
As neere to danger, as the next to death,
Be confident in me, the zeale I beare,
To the sincere profession of the truth,
Is a sure guard for you to trust vpon.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: The poorest Princes, only rich in faith,
Will pay you a large bounty of her praiers,
Remember then you call me Mistrisse White,
For by that name I past from Billings-gate,
Thence to Graues-end, and so from thence to Lee,
Where vnder your protection we remayne.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: In every place we heere the Hue and Cry,
Pursue our fearefull flight, in every towne
We heare the voyce of persecution.

sp.speaker: Craenw.
sp.l: And harke I heere the officers within
If we be knowne, we are but dead.

sp.speaker: Gosel.
sp.l: Tush Mistrisse White,
That name shall giue free scope vnto your flight.

sp.speaker: Consta
sp.l: Good you, good even M. Gosseling,
Good you, good even.

sp.speaker: Gosel.
sp.l: Welcome good M. Constable,
whats the newes with you.

sp.speaker: Consta.
sp.p: Marry wee haue a warrant heere from the high Commission, to seeke for a Dutches, and certaine other People, that are in her company, as Doctor Sands, and one Master Cranwell, her Gentleman-vsher, we are commanded to search your house for such suspected Persons.

sp.speaker: Gosel.
sp.l: See M. Constable, with me remaines
No more then these, if Mistris White my daughter,
Come with her Child, and Nurse to visit me,
With this her husband, this her husbands father,
If you thinke her a Dutches, him a Doctor,
Then you may apprehend them at your pleasure,
If not, you had best to make a further search,
For I protest, no stranger more then these,
Harbors within my roofe.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I take your word sir, and yet I wil not, I wil search within.
She a Dutches blesse her good Woman,
Good Mistris White y'ar welcome to Lee, as I may say within.
We haue an honest neighbor of your Father,
Is this your Child, heaven blesse the little mopps,
Alack, alack, it is as like the Grand-sire
As ever it may looke, my pretty ducke.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Where's M. Constable, haue you made search,
In these suspitious houses.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Good heaven protect vs, now we are betraid,
This Villaine will, I feare, discover vs.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: I know her, them, and all.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Good M. Goseling stand to vs now,
Or we are betrayd.

sp.speaker: Gosel.
sp.l: Get you into my house.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Stand there attend there M. Constable,
My M. Doctor Bonner in disguise,
Stayes at the gate, let me survey these parties.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Thou knowest vs Fox, wee haue bin fellow servants,
Confer the yeeres past, with the present times,
And it will make thy flinty heart relent.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: I know thee not.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: O Fox, she hath bin the most honord Mistris,
That ever servant serued, stay me,
And whilst their bloody hands are busied,
With ceising me, let her, and these escape.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Peace fellow, now no fellowes, thy Mistr. when she was
In prosperity, turn'd me off, and therefore I will not know
Her in extremity.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Wilt thou not know her in extremity,
Vngratefull villaine.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: No sir, I will not, I come to looke a Dutches,
Woman be gon, I know thee not, thou a Doct, thou a dunce,
Get thee gon, Cranwell I knew, he was my fellow servant,
Thee I know not, thou art a paultrey fellow,
Away Goseling, take in your geese,
Ship them at your pleasure, when the coast is cleere,
I my selfe will giue you a watch-word.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: The fellow may meane well, let vs withdraw.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I now perceiue, I haue done his faith much wrong,
His heart has no relation to his tongue.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Away, whers the Constable.
Heeres neither Cranwell, Sands, Dutches, nor Child,
Goe call in my Lord Bonner.

sp.speaker: Bonn.
sp.l: Fox.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: What hast thou found them Fox?

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: My Lord we had a wrong intelligence,
But thus you shall surprise them, passe they cannot
But by this way, now will we watch these passages,
For now the tide's at height, if they intend
To ship themselues, it must be presently,
Place your selfe heere, directly by this well,
By you Clunie, heere I meane to stand,
Guard that place well, by me this shall be mand.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Stand by me Clunie, Fox, ile pay thee well,
If by thy meanes we catch these miscreants,
Twill bee thy making Fox, M. Cunstable where will you stand.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Let him keepe that way, that beares to landward,
That way, I am sure they will not take,
Goe make a strong watch there.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I warrant you M. Fox, let vs alone to guard that passage.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: My Lord, you had best sit for your ease.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Oh I could watch houres, daies, nights, moneths, yeeres,
So I might see their hearts weepe bloody teares.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Looke you stand sure Lord Bonner, for I hope,
Anon youle neede a bucket, and a rope.

div.stage: Enter Goseling, Dutches, Sands, Cranwell, Nurse, and Childe.

sp.speaker: Gose.
sp.l: Keepe close together, lest you loose your trayne,
My barke is ready to receaue you straight,
That way you neede must take, Ile not be seene,
Heaven be your guide, with me you haue not bin.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Good sir farewell, my prayers on you attend,
I will report you for a Princes friend.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Stand, trust me and keepe on,
What ere you see shrinke not, away begon,
My Lord they come, they come, away, away.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Helpe, helpe, for heavens sake helpe.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: My Lord is in the well.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: A rope for Bishop Bonner, Clunie run,
Call helpe, a rope, or we are all vndone.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Ile to the watch for helpe.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Helpe, helpe, good Fox.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Soft Bonner, not too fast
Heere is no comming out till they be past,
My armes too short my Lord, a rope is comming.

div.stage: Enter Clunie, Constable, Watch, with Ropes.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Heere in this well, ropes, ropes my masters.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: By this they are far enough,
Well done my Masters, lends your hands,
Draw Dun out of the ditch.
Draw, pull, helpe all, so, so, well done.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Oh Fox oh Clunie, oh my Masters all,
I am almost drown'd, oh lead me to some fire.
Oh Fox, what meanest thou to rush with such rude force.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: What would you haue me doe, I saw them comming,
And I had not the power to stay my selfe.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: And are they past.

sp.speaker: Gose.
sp.l: What stand you trifeling here, what seeke you for?
If for the Dutches, if for Doctor Sands,
For Cranwell, and the rest, they in disguise,
Are got abord a Ship, and with full sailes,
Flye from the Shore.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Thou telst me a sad tale,
Post Fox, run Clunie, hire a Barke with speede,
Goseling we were suspitious of thy faith,
But by this message, thou hast cleer'd thy selfe,
See Goseling, I am almost drownd.

sp.speaker: Gos.
sp.l: I am sorry for your honor, that you scap't.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Tush we trifle time in their vaine pursute,
Thou shalt haue gold Fox; Clunie, thou reward,
Helpe me to fire good Goseling, Fox away,
We loose much expedition by thy stay.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Ile after them my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: May all things prosper to thy hearts desire,
Come Goseling, prethee lead me to a fire.

div.stage: Enter Bartie, and Pericell a Walloune.

sp.speaker: Bertie.
sp.l: And as I told you sir, with that excuse,
I grounded this my colorable passage,
And sent a ship, which staies for her at Lee,
Where by appointment she had promis'd meeting,
But She is so watcht, so guarded, and so bard,
Of her true servants presence and accesse,
That I despaire of her arrivall here.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: Good M. Bertie, cheere your drooping thoughts,
We are Walloones, but in subiection,
And strict obedience to the church of Rome,
Rewards and promises, are sent abroad,
To every forreine Prince, and Burgomaster,
To stay the Dutches, for the rumor runns,
She is escapt already from her house.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Tis very certaine M. Pericell,
Now shall we heare some newes,
Here's Doctor Sands.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: Newes of the Dutches, that will please but ill,
I will forbeare to speake of our escapes,
All which were wing'd, with fortune, and successe,
And tell you of one haplesse accident,
We all tooke Ship at Lee, but not together,
For I alone past in a Hollander,
No sooner did the wind blow from the shore,
But rose a tempest, which disperst our ships,
And we might see the Barke wherein she went,
By violence of the waues forc'd backe againe,
Even to the havens mouth.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Even to deaths leane armes,
Thy tragicke newes, hath slaine me M. Sands,
We are as one, and what beside her person,
I feele in a true essence of her griefe.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: In these extreames, tis good to hope the best.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Oh M. Perecill, the worst of ills,
Falls on her head, and can I hope the best,
Shees like a Lambe, trapt with a heard of Wolues,
A harmelesse Doue amongst a thousand Haukes,
If she return'd, what providence can saue,
A body doom'd already to the graue.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: See M. Bertie, lift vp your sad eyes.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Bertie.

sp.speaker: Bertie.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: Oh see the meeting of two faithfull soules,
What a sweete vnion it doth make of hearts,
When one another mutuall ioy imparts.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Defer the story, of our dangers past,
To acquaint vs with some comfortable ayd.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Oh pardon me one minute gentle Madam,
If I delay your faire request a little,
To take my fellow servants by the hand,
Good M. Cranwell, the firme loyalty,
You beare you Mistrisse, in her great extreames,
Shall be recorded in a booke of Brasse.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Alas I haue scanted of my duty much,
My liberall will's ioyn'd with vnable power,
With my true service I doe ioyne my life,
And owe them both, vnto your princely Wife.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: You are a Mirror, Nurse, so art thou,
Thy noble carriage, thus I Kisse with ioy,
Alas poore Lady, thou, ere thou canst goe,
Art forst to leaue thy countrey, thy returne,
Will make them smile, that now are forst to mourne,
Thy infancy in Pilgrimage is spent,
Yet thy abode heereafter shall be Kent,
And be an honord Countesse of that name,
For so my true divining spirits doe ayme.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: What Gentleman is that.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Tis a Walloone Feris de Ryviers, alias Perecell.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: May we repose with him?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Madam you may not,
Neither in this place may I challenge you,
For I am noted, and your comming hither,
Both promised, and expected by great men,
Who to surprise you, haue receiv'd reward,
All Ports are laid, all passages are stop't,
Search, and inquirie posts through every towne.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: Madam tis true, nor would I haue you stay,
In Emden long, for you are laid for heere.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: What shall we then doe?

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: Madam, lets to Santon,
Let M. Bertie stay with Perecell,
And meete vs there heereafter.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Content, let it be so,
Never two lovers, Married to more woe,
Heere meete we, and heere part we, oh short pleasure,
Which fortune serues vs, in too small a measure.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: My body is devided in the midst,
That way goes halfe my heart, and this way tother,
Necessity thy sterne deeds I beshrow,
That thy rude hand, giues vs the parting blow,
At Santon I will meete you Madam, heere
I dare not know you, so adue my deere.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Berty farewell, to Santon bound we are,
With these companions, and our conduct care,
You people happy in a land of peace,
That ioy your consciences, with the worlds increase,
Looke with indifference into my sad life,
Heere my poore husband, dares not know his wife,
And I a Princes, to avoid like danger,
Must vse my owne deere husband, as a stranger,
Towards Santon we, through deserts, any way,
Though all should leaue me, I for griefe must stay.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Madam, you see what strictnes, we are forced to.
Lets wing our feet, till we can get to Santon,

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: Madam, let me admire your constancy,
For heaven hath prov'd your patience every way,
Yet you are confident, and more your zeale to trie,
Yo'r forst your loyall husband to deny,

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Then what pale trembling cowards heart would faint,
To wade through danger with so pure a saint?

sp.speaker: 1. Thiefe.
sp.l: A bootie, stend, dispoyle them, downe with them.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: We are beset with theeues.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: Sands, thou must flie,
For weaponles, thou canst no mastery try.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Theeues, theeues.

sp.speaker: 1. Theefe.
sp.l: Pursue them not, lets ceise on them that stay,

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Slaues, you haue murderd me.

sp.speaker: Theefe.
sp.l: No matter, ceise on her, and rifle both,
Ha, by my faith a gallant lusty wench,
Tis the best booty, that we met this moneth.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Oh my true servants death, doth grieue me more,
Then all the sorrowes that I felt before.

div.stage: They drawe her aside to rifle her.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I am iealous of the safety of my wife,
And to escape the better through the woods,
I haue cloath'd my selfe thus in an Out-lawes shape,
Oh, sight of ruth, my fellow Cranwell slaine:
My wife graspt in the armes of ravishers,
Then heaven instruct me with some present meanes,
That I may find some aid to rescue them,
I haue it, a booty, a booty, a braue booty:
But we want helpe, and ayd to compasse it,
Foure wealthy Merchants, are come downe this hill,
Some little ayd, and we shall share them all.

sp.speaker: 2. Thiefe.
sp.l: Some of you looke to see the Woman safe,
Ile helpe to take the booty.

sp.speaker: 3. Thiefe.
sp.l: And so will I.

sp.speaker: 1. Thiefe.
sp.l: One bird ith' hand's worth two ith' bush:
Ile take my present purchase.

sp.speaker: 2. Thiefe.
sp.l: Weele share a both sides, come conduct vs to them.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I will, stirre not from hence with her,
Till we returne.

sp.speaker: 1. Theefe.
sp.l: My life for yours, come, will you vncase.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Doe not disrobe me of my clothes, as y'ar a man.

sp.speaker: 1. Theefe.
sp.l: Tut, stand not vpon tearmes,
I loue to see a Woman naked.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Defend me heaven.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: So ho, ho, I haue lost a Iewell,
And left it heere behind, when I departed hence.

sp.speaker: 1. Theefe.
sp.l: What valew.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: More pretious then thy soule, and this it is,
Villaine, thinke not to scape, your mates are far enough.

sp.speaker: 1. Theefe.
sp.l: How goodman rascall.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Thus, Villaine, for the world,
I would not stayne my hands with thy base blood:
But rascall, I will bind you to the peace,
So now, let this ditch shelter you.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: My Berty? heaven be prais'd,
Though I am rob'd of all the wealth I haue,
I am rich enough, in my possessing thee,

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Is M. Cranwell slaine?

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: But sorely hurt, and I am neere to death.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Bind vp your wounds, with this white hankercher,

sp.speaker: Bertie,
sp.l: I am so vs'd to misery,
That it seemes nothing, wheres the Nurse and Child?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Oh crosse on crosse, lets looke about the woods.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: My Susan lost, I will not stir one foot,
But to the Villaines be a second prey,
Vnlesse I find her.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Lend me your hand deere sir, get I once vp,
Ile spend the remnant of my blood thats left,
In search of my young Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.l: Oh whither shall I flie, to saue my life,
From the rude hands of these fell ravishers?
My haplesse Lady, and her husband both,
By this, haue felt the cruell stroake of death,
Or which is worse, are captiue led away,
sp.stage: Noise within so ho, ho Nurse
sp.l: And to the Vulters gripes become a prey,
Oh harke, I heare them comming, hence begone,
Hard is thy hap, that must be left alone,
Deere babe forgiue me, I am forc'd for life,
To ease my carriage, leaue thee to their strife.
On forwards Madam, this way they are gone,
Heaven be propitions, direct vs in our search.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Amen, amen.

div.stage: Enter Cranwell staggering, and falls neere the Bush where the Child is.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Oh I am lost, sinke body to the earth,
Ascend my soule, mongst Saints receaue new birth.

sp.speaker: Dutc.
sp.l: Helpe Bertie, helpe, tis Cranwell faints, oh helpe.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Speake to me man, looke vp, some wound belike
Is yet vnstopt, from whence proceeds this large effusion,
Its heere, lend me some linnen, so, so, he comes againe,
And see heavens bounty, he at once hath given,
Your Servant, and your Child: looke Madam, see,
Throwne in a bush, and smiles, and laughes at yee.

sp.speaker: Dutc.
sp.l: Having my Husband, Child, and this my servant,
I am the richest Princes on the earth,
But Berty, where's the Nurse, and Docter Sands.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Both fled, but wherefore Madam looke you pale.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Oh Berty, I doe feele the time approach
Of my delivery, oh for helpe of Women.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: What shall we doe, I am beyond my selfe.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Cranwell, what towne is this that stands before.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Madam, they call it Wezill.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Goe, begon,
Thy lookes pleads for a cunning Surgeon,
We shall not neede, thy helpe, thy wound is deepe,
But stay you Bertie, you the Child must keepe.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Madam, this storme, the cold, and my deep wounds,
May well excuse me, till my hurts are drest.

sp.speaker: Dutch:
sp.l: Be gon I say.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: How fare you Madam.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Sicke I am, heaven knowes,
Ready to die, with these my pinching throwes,
It raines, and hailes, and snowes, and blowes at once,
Where Berty, may we hide vs from this storme.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Here in this Church-porch, Madam pray remoue,

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Helpe, and leade me thither, now lay the Child downe Berty.
Goe gather sticks, to helpe to make a fire,
More plagues my sinnes doe merit yeere by yeere,
But these, good heavens, are more then I can beare.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Alas, alas, this is a homely place,
To bring a Princesse of such state to bed,
A wide Church-porch, is made her bed-chamber,
And the cold stones her couch, here are no curtaines,
But the bleke Windes, could Clouds and stormes of hayle,
And they begirt her round, heaven for thy mercy,
This poore distressed Princes shield and saue,
Whose cold head lies vpon some dead mans graue,
Heere comes the Sexton, I will speake to him,
It may be, he may helpe vs to releife.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Gods sacrament vat maukt ye dare.

sp.speaker: Bert,
sp.l: Patience good sir.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Vat bedlers in den kerke, loopt hence strax.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Vncivell fellow, what thou speakest, I know not,
But thy ill meaning by thy deeds, I guesse:
Take that to teach thee more civillity.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Out skellum one hundred towsan divel.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Still fortune is against vs, this base fellow
Will raise some tumult to betray our liues,
Yet yonder comes & man of gravity,
It may be he can speake the Latine tongue,
In that Ile let him vnderstand my griefe:
Optime & ornatissime vir, audi quaeso.

sp.speaker: Eras.
sp.l: Quis es qui tot clamoribus, & tanta exclamatione,
Non modo Divinum Cenatorij locum irreverenter &
Orrose occupas, at vrbem tam claram civesque & Senatores,
Propter etates suas adoratissimas tam flactiose disturbas.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Si cum fronte tam generosa cor tuum humanum consentire
Videtur, infortunij nostri miserere.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Erasmus Roterodamus propter miserias vestras toto corde
Dolet, colo perfectiones & virtutes, quas intimo meo animo
Complectar, multi pendo.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Is this Erasmus borne in Roterdam,
He that so highly lou'd Sir Thomas More?

sp.speaker: Erasm.
sp.l: Portate hanc ad domum Francisci de Ryvers alias Perecell
Sic domino dominaeque Erasmus Rotero damus omnibus
Officijs est observantissimus.

div.stage: They beare her off in a Chayre. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus Quartus.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Within this towne hath Perecell a house,
There, by the credit of this learned man,
We haue got harbor till the moneth expire,
In which her heavy burthen may be eas'd,
Good heaven looke downe vpon her misery,
Comfort her in her griefe, strengthen her weakenesse,
Lay not our woes to wretched Bonners charge,
Free her sweete heaven, by thy Almighty hand,
That we may once revisite our owne land.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Now cheere your selfe deere sir, here is a time,
To breath a space, this towne's a quiet port,
From the tempestuous gusts of Bonners hate.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.l: Some refuge I confesse, but the distressed Dutches,
In Child-bed torment is a fresh alarum
Of new sprung care, I cannot be at quiet,
Vntill her safe deliuery be past.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Doubt not of that, the powerfull hand of heaven,
In such extremities is ever strong.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Good heaven, when I recount the miseries
We haue already past, me thinkes the lottery
Of cruell Fortune, should be quite exhaust,
And yet when I record the name of Bonner,
With his desire to become great by blood,
The greater part of woe seemes still behind.

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: Doubtlesse hees of a most pernitious spirit,
But he that hath restrain'd his envious rage,
And hitherto repulst him, still will curbe him.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I trust he will, Cranwell I prethee step,
And listen from the women what good newes.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: Pray saue that labour, we can bring the newes.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Welcome good Doctor Sands,
What; in good health?

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: Sir, thanks to heaven, who never leaues his owne
Nor suffers them to perish in distresse.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: How fares the Dutches.
Gentle host resolue me.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: Happy and well, cheere your declining thoughts,
Well that her perillous conflict hath an end,
And happy that to comfort her withall,
Theres borne this day a young Lord Willobie.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: A Boy.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: A goodly Boy M. Bertie.
And one in whom already doth appeare,
These signes of Courage, to revenge your wrongs.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Good heaven I thanke thee,
This your newes deere friend,
Is as a summons after death to life, the preservation
Of his mother in travell, was wonderous strange,
The place where he is borne is strange,
The loving hands, that did first entertayne
His presence to this pilgrimage of life,
Are likewise strange, then as his birth hath bin,
So shall his name, weele call him Peregrine.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: A stranger to his Countrey by that name,
But by his deeds hereafter time may prooue,
None more adventured for his Countreys loue.

div.stage: A Drum beats a soft March.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: As it please his starres, but soft,
What Drum is this, some galle I feare,
To intermix our sweete,
Some sorrow to confound this sudden joy.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: Your servant Fox did vow to bring you word,
If any hurt were secretly pretended.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Is Fox arived, vpon what cause,
Is Fox arived, vpon what cause
Is he past over, doe you know gentle sir.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: Himselfe make answer for himselfe.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Sir, be not you dismayd, in breife these drums,
And those that after these sad Musicke daunce,
Are none that wish you, nor the Dutches good,
A Captayne sent from England, and the bloodhound Clunie,
With them the Duke of Brunswicke, clad in armes,
And at the least, ten Ensignes after him,
These how ere they vizard their intents,
With other colour, as to vexe the Emperour,
Yet their whole purpose, is to looke for you,
The gates, and walls, are every way beset,
And through the Towne, a privy search begun,
And but you presently devise some meanes,
To scape from hence, theyle take you in your lodging.

sp.speaker: Bertie.
sp.l: Escape, theres now no time to talke of scape,
No, no, the secret providence of heaven,
Hath so ordain'd, we should be Bonner thrall,
And welcome wished death, the end of all.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: My mind presageth of a better speed.
What M. Bertie why not now escape,
As well as heeretofore.

sp.speaker: Bertie.
sp.l: How can that be,
The painefull Dutches, lying now in Child-bed.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: Is there no art, no meanes to blind their eyes.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: You are so many of you, tis impossible,
Besides the Dutches, she cannot remooue.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Oh, were she safe, I car'd not for my life.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: Nor I for mine.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Nor I, had I ten thousand liues,

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: Cease you your passions, my braine hath tutord me,
And in a cunning plot shall set you free.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Doe that, and Bertie is for ever thine.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Fox, and his sword, for that will be thy slaue.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: Thy friendship will I beare vnto my graue.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: What thou attempt'st,
My prayers shall helpe to second.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: I neither doe expect thankes, nor reward,
But what I doe is of meere charity,
Then list vnto me, there's a friend of mine,
A Countrey Gentleman, not far from hence,
Whose brother late returned from the warres,
And falling sicke, within the Citty heere,
Dyed some few dayes since, now this Gentleman,
Because his brother shall be buried,
Amongst his Ancestors, decrees this night,
To haue his body in a Wagon brought,
Home to the Parish Church, where he remaines,
And for that purpose hath his servants sent,
To see it safe conveyd: A waggon like to theirs,
Covered with blacke, shall be provided straight,
Into the which, by helpe of Womens hands,
The Dutches, and her Infant shall be lifted,
You, and the rest disguis'd in mourning weeds,
Shall follow after as the guard,
And in the dead Mans name without suspect,
Passe by the Souldiers, who if they chance,
To question who you are,
The Burgers being by, and made acquainted,
With such a herce, that is to passe that way,
Will quickly answer them, without more search,
How like you this.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: It will I hope proue currant.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: The pretext is fit, and for the Dutches ease:

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Fox has no more sence then a batle-doore,
If in his iudgement, we already be not
Delivered from the mischiefe of their hands.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.l: Come Ile provide you all things necessary.
And after pray for your successe therein.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Ile backe to them, and helpe you what I can.

div.stage: Enter Brunswick, L. Paget, Portgraue, Clunie, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Paget.
sp.l: Great Duke of Brunswick, this your flexible,
And curteous disposition of your troopes,
To be for Englands service, shall receaue
The due belongeth to so great a merit.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: Noble Captaine, I were much to be condemned,
If I neglect my duty to the Church,
But are you sure, these fugetiues are heere?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: Clunie, thou touldst me, that thou sawest a man
Of theirs, since we beset the towne wast true?

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Yes noble Captaine, Cranwell the Dutches vsher,
And there's no question, but the rest are heere,

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Well then Captaine, the other Ports being garded,
Heere with this company weele keepe our station,
Where is the Portgraue? haue you sent abroad,
Sufficient search amongst the private houses?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: We haue my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: They cannot be in Weasell,
But either comming forth, or lurking heere,
They must in all sorts be discovered by vs.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Oh they are politick, and passing subtile,
And if or art, or policie, can helpe them,
There's in their company, an Instrument.
Can plot a hundred wales for their escape.

sp.speaker: Brun.
sp.l: Let them expresse their cunning, if they can,
And scape our hands, now we haue sented them.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: How now my Lord, oh I am out of breath,
In comming to you, yet I hope my hast,
Is little for your purpose, they are comming,
Stand on your guard, for this way they must passe,
Ther's Bertie, Cranwell, Sands, with them the Dutches,

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Twas well done Fox, there's thy reward, stand close,
Or, now, or never, let vs shew our care, stand, who goes there?

div.stage: Enter foure, bearing a Hearce, Bertie, Sands, Cranwell, Mourners.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: Some funerall it seemes.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: It may be some device procured by them,
So to escape the danger of our watch, stand.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: I can assure your Lordship, tis not so,
This is the body of young Vandermast,
Whose brother dwelling some foure leagues from hence,
Although he died heere, yet will haue him buried,
Whereas his Ancestors are all intomb'd,
And for that cause, hath sent his servants for him.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: Is it no otherwise.

sp.speaker: Berty.
sp.l: No mighty Prince,
And would to heaven it had not bin so now:

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Passe then, passe, it is not you we looke for.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: What was this Vandermast, a Cittizen?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: No my good Lord, he was a Souldier,
A proper Gentleman, and one had served
The Emperour, and others in their warres,
Yet was ordain'd, to end his dayes at home.

sp.speaker: Bruns
sp.l: A thing no more then vsuall, but how now,
Whats here, an other funerall? nay then
It is a hazzard, we are all deluded.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: My thoughts began to prophecie as much,
Speake, are not you the parties that even now
Came this way, with a mourning funerall.

sp.speaker: 1. Mour.
sp.l: Not we my Lord, this is the first appearance,
We made this evening.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: What haue you there conceal'd.

sp.speaker: 1. Mour.
sp.l: Nothing my Lord, but a dead body Coffin'd,
The brother of our M. late deceast.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: I, this is Vandermast, the other past,
Vpon my life, was Barty, and the Dutches.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: They were vnwilling to looke vp me thought.

sp.speaker: Bruns:
sp.l: And he that spake, spake with a fained voice.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Twas they, twas they, oh, I could teare my haire,
To thinke we were so grossely overseene.

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.l: I said as much, come let vs follow them,
Send horsemen out, to every quarter straight,
My Lord of Brunswick.

sp.speaker: Bruns:
sp.l: You need not bid me ride,
This oversight, hath clapt wings to my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Now for some pretty policy againe,
To lead them forth the way, vntill the Dutches,
May reach Polonia, and deserue the prize,
Fox play thy part, some stratagem devise.

sp.speaker: Bonn.
sp.l: Wher sits the winde, no newes from Germany?
If those malitious fugitiues be tayne,
Our officers I feare, neglect their charge,
Our Captaine deales but coldly with the States.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: I dreamt my Lord, that Bertie and the Dutches,
Were both advanc't vpon a regall throne,
And had their temples wreath'd with glittering gold.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: That throne doe I interpret, is the stage
Of horrid death, these wreathes of Gold, bright flames,
That shall not onely circle in their browes,
But wind about their bodies, till they waste,
And be converted to a heape of ashes,
Me thinks this worke of ours goes slowly forward,
The ayre of England freezeth for defect
Of burning Meteors, to keepe it warme.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: See yet my Lord, there hath of late bin sacrific'd,
In sundry places, many persons, of severall qualities,
Whose names were tedious to relate.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Tut this is nothing, every towne should blaze,
And every streete, in every towne looke red,
With glowing sinders of the Miscreants:
Till like to Cockle, they were quite extinct,
And nothing seene to florish but pure Corne:
The morning spends apace, where are these knaues,
Appointed to bring Fagots for the fire,
Wherein bold Latimer, and Ridley must expire.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: They come my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bonner.
sp.l: Fye on you loytering knaues,
Why make you not more hast, be gon, I say,
And see the stake, and every thing be ready,
See how I am still procrastinated,
The Maior of Oxford, meanes to dyne I thinke,
Before he bring the Prisoners to the stake,
How now? where are they?

sp.speaker: Sherife.
sp.l: Hard at hand my Lord,
But the weake age of Latimer is such,
They cannot come so fast, as else they would,
Besides some disputations as they passe,
Had with the Schollers, hath detayn'd their speede.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: He haue no disputations, bring them on.

div.stage: Enter Latimer, and Ridley, with Halberds.

sp.speaker: Ridley.
sp.l: Come brother Latimer, lend me your arme,
The weake, the weake, but not the blind, the blind,
This day in Oxford, shall be seene to guide.

sp.speaker: Lati.
sp.l: My heart is iocund, brother Ridley, still,
