And in my Spirit, I flye vnto yon place,
But these weake withered saplins are too blame,
These legs of mine, that having now at least,
Full foure score and eight winters done me service,
Should now deceaue me trust me, but my soule is
Linct in charity, with all the world,
I could be well content, to chide with them.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: These are those selfe iustifying Publicans,
Away with them, conduct them to the fire.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Come, come, spend no time in talke,
Will you convert, be sorie for your crime,
And you shall yet finde favor with the Queene.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Fye, fye, spit at them, offer them no mercy.

sp.speaker: Ridley.
sp.l: Proceed in scorne, so was our Master vs'd,
The servants are not better then their Lord,

sp.speaker: Bonn.
sp.l: Drag them away there, hence away I say.

sp.speaker: Cranm.
sp.l: Stay, stay.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Which voyce is that.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Some one thats prisoner in Bocardo heere,

sp.speaker: Cranm.
sp.l: Oh stay my Lords, whom leade you there to death?
The reverent fathers, Ridley, and Latimer?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: I Cranmer, but more fauor rests for thee,
Because thou art converted from thine errors.

sp.speaker: Cranm.
sp.l: Did you not tell me, they were likewise changed,
And haue you falsely circumvented me?
Oh heaven, forgiue my trayterous revolte,
And you the chosen vessels of his loue,
Deere Latimer, sweete Ridley pardon me,
To make amends, Ile come and dye with you.

sp.speaker: Lati.
sp.l: As your revolt, graue Cranmer, was our griefe,
So to heare these repentant gracefull words,
Infuse our hearts with ioy, beyond compare.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Will Cranmer then turne, and returne againe.

sp.speaker: Cranm.
sp.l: To turne to vertue never comes to late.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Thy recantation vnderneath thy hand,
Is publisht, and wilt thou now contradict it.

sp.speaker: Cranm.
sp.l: Bonner, to cut off needlesse circumstance,
Let this declare my resolution,
This hand that writ that faithlesse recantation,
Since I am bard from dying with my friends,
Marke how I punish in this lingring flame,
It shall burne off, as an assured signe,
Heereafter of my constant Martyrdome,
No scandall shall be left by my default,
Open you heavens, and entertaine my willing sacrifice,
Yet this is but an earnest of that loue,
Heereafter shall in greater measure shine.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Iaylor pull downe that scismatick,
Lodge him within the dungeon, loade his ioynts
With Iron fetters, let him fast from meate,
And haue no comfort, but continuall checks, dispatch, I say.

sp.speaker: Cranm.
sp.l: Farewell religious mates,
What earth doth separate, I hope ere long,
Shall meet in heaven, spight of proud Bonners tongue.

sp.speaker: Rid.
sp.l: Farewell kind brother, nere decline no more,
But follow vs, as we haue gone before.

sp.speaker: Laty.
sp.l: What stay we for, my quiet thoughts desire,
To cloth this flesh, in purple robes of fire.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: You shall not neede to vrge our expedition,
Leade them away, their Tragedy once ended,
We will prepare attentiue eares to heare,
Newes of the Dutches landing prisoner.

div.stage: Enter Dutches, and Bertie, with their Children.

sp.speaker: Dutches.
sp.l: Yet we haue scapt the danger of our foes,
And I that whilom was exceeding weake,
Through my hard travell in this infants birth,
Am now growne strong vpon necessity,
How forwards are we towards Windam Castle.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Iust halfe our way, but we haue lost our friends,
Through the hot pursute of our enemies.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: We are not vtterly devoyd of friends,
Behold the young Lord Willowby smiles on vs,
And tis great helpe, to haue a Lord our Friend.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Good heaven I pray once sorte to happy end,
This dangerous Pilgrimage, heere vndertooke,
Sit on this banke a while, and rest our limbes,
Wearied with travaile, as our minds with care.

div.stage: Enter Fox, Clunie, Captaine, and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: You are a Captaine of the Palsegraues band,
These are the other recreants, ceaze them both,
The hundred Crownes propos'd, are surely yours,
I know him valiant, and therefore I will clyme
Vp in this tree, to see, and not be seene,
Pray lends a hand, whil'st you surprise them,
I will laughing stand.

sp.speaker: Fox,
sp.l: If I fit you not, ere you come downe,
Say Fox is a Goose.

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: Sir I attach you as an enemy
Vnto the Palsegraue, in whose land you are,
You and you Trull, obey it ye were best,
Or in resistance hazzard both your liues.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Attach me sir, I know no reason why,
Nor to my knowledge am an enemy,
Vnto the Palsgraue, or the meanest man
Within his confines, wer are Travellers,
And will immediatly forsake the land.

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: You are a Launce knight, this your Concubine.
And these your Bastards, that by rapine liue,
And thus disguis'd you come to vndermine,
Our Countries government, then yeeld your selues.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Though misery hath stampt vpon out brow
The marke of poverty, yet gentle stranger,
Doe not so far forget all manlinesse,
To be a slanderer of the Innocent.

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: Terme me a slanderer.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: And a Villaine too, if thou maintayne these defamations,
Terme me a Thiefe, my wife a Concubine,
My Children base borne; by a souldiers faith,
Wert thou the greatest spirit the Palesgraue hath,
I cannot brooke this slavish insolence,
That I am angry, witnesse this reply,
I will defend mine honour though I dye.

sp.speaker: 2. Cap.
sp.l: Villaines I charge you all inviron him,

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: So many to one silly passenger,
Then farewell woman weakenes, welcome sword,
For once Ile play the man, to saue my Lord.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Why this is excellent, now I hope to liue
To see them apprehended or else slayne.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: These hopes Ile crosse, by cutting downe the branch
Whereon he builds this weake foundation.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Oh I shall fall, helpe me good M. Fox.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: I, wherefore Clunie, to betray my Lady?
So hatefull Bonner, dived into the well,
So fall this damned Parator to hell,
And now Ile helpe my Mistris to my power,
Fox, come out a your hole, and take your Cozens part
Or Ile pull you out by the eares.
Helpe, helpe, our Captaines murthered, raise the towne.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: The Captaine slaine then Fox tis best to flie,
And lest some sad mischance should second them,
I will convey these Children to the Woods,
That borders neere at hand, oh heaven I pray,
Make this disasterous time a happy day.
Cry within .Helpe, helpe, our Captaynes slayne.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: I must downe, blesse my necke and care not.
Cry within .Follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Oh, my guts, a vengeance on this Fox.
Cry within .This way, this way follow.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: What cries are these, oh hast thou slaine the Cap.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: If he be slaine, require not heaven his blood,
Of miserable Berty.
Within .Helpe, helpe, helpe.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: A second volley of heart wounding words,
Oh flye my loue, flye, flye, and saue thy life,
Before the towne be rais'd, shift for your selfe,
If you be taken, theres no way but death.
Within. Heere, heere, this way.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Why stir you not, our foes are hard at hand.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I am so amaz'd I know not where to goe,
Ile take this way.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Rather deere Loue take this.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: That way they come.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: What shall we doe,
Behold a Ladder rais'd against this house,
In happy time, mount vp and saue your life,
I will defend the bottome with my sword,
And though heaven knowes I am orelaid with woe,
Ile rather dye then see your overthrow.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: But I shall leaue thee to thine enemies.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Shift for your owne life, take, no care for mine,
For heavens sake quickly, you delay the time.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Feare lend me wings, but oh my griefs so great,
It waies me downe, and I must needs retreat.
Cry within .Come away, come away, ho! come away.

sp.speaker: Dutch,
sp.l: They are at hand, oh good my loue mount vp.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: See where they are that made the fray.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: You fellow, that run vp the Ladder,
Downe, downe, or Ile pull you downe in a ropes name.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: He is my husband, and a Gentleman,
And Ile defend him from your tyranie.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: A Woman fight.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Such are my fortunes now,
Therefore keepe off, who ventures on this way,
Treadeth a path that leadeth to his death.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: My friends what seeke you, wherefore come you arm'd?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: You haue slaine a Captaine of the Palsgraves Band
Wounded his souldiers, and besides we heare,
You are a Lanceknight, this your Concubine,
And come disguis'd to vndermine the State,
In whose defence these men haue arm'd themselues.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: You seeme a Burgomaster, by your habit,
And they that mis-inform'd you were too blame,
Know gentle sir, I am an Englishman,
And on some speciall busines bound this way,
Toward Windam-Castle, till we were disturb'd,
By the oppression of the man that's slayne.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: I wreake not friend of what estate you are,
Nor to what end you travaile through these parts,
You haue slaine a map, and you must answer it,
According to the law of Nations.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Downe with him, he shall answer it with death.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: Peace there, I charge you, in the Princes name.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: It seemes these men are thirsty for my blood,
And without law are set to take my life,
Then it were madnesse for a man to yeeld,
To abide a triall, and the iudgement past:
Since I must dye, Ile choose the death my selfe,
And thats to stand on a defensiue guard,
Except you sweare as you'r a Christian,
A Magistrate, and one that will doe right,
That I shall haue due processe of the Law
And be defended from the multitude.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Doe not, I pray, indanger so your life,
But trust vnto the shelter you haue got.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: A sorry fortresse to defend his life.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: But will you take that oath.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: By heaven I doe, and I will see it kept inviolate.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Then worke the worst of fate, if right beare sway,
He cannot speed amisse that does no wrong,
Oh, innocence is bold, free, liberall,
Fearelesse of any danger, that may fall,
I yeeld me sir, a Prisoner to the law,
Iustice is blind gaze not vpon our persons,
Although our birth be neare so meane or base,
But fixe the eye of iudgement on our case.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: So, bind their hands, & lead them to the statehouse,
They shall haue iustice done immediately,

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Oh stay a while, I haue lost my little babes,
What savadge hand hath tane my children hence,
Whil'st we were busied in this lucklesse brawle.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: My Children borne away! oh then I feare,
It is some treason to abridge our liues,
And that the Captaine, that did wrong vs thus,
Did it to that intent.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Tis so, till now we nere were truely miserable,
Our other miseries were sunneshine dayes,
Compar'd vnto the greatnesse of this storme,
Oh suffer me good sir, to seeke them out,
For without them, I am but halfe my selfe.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: A strict enquiry shall be made foorthwith,
In every place that borders heere abouts,
Greeue not too much, though such are poore mens treasure,
What needy thiefe to steale them would take pleasure.

div.head: Actus Quintus.
div.stage: Enter Burgomaster, Bertie, Dutches, followed by Souldiers: other side, Palsegraue, Erbaigh, and Lords attendants.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.l: Right welcome's Erbaigh, to the Poland king,
Nich'as Van houe, our worthy Burgomaster,
What meanes this concourse of so many men,
And what are they that you lead bound with you.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: Strangers, an please your excellence my Lord,
That haue committed murder in your realme,
Slaine Wisendrop a Captaine of your band,
For which offence, our purpose is to lead them,
vnto the State-house to receiue their iudgement.

sp.speaker: Erba.
sp.l: If I mistake not, I should know that face,
Oh tis the vertuous Lady Katherine,
This M. Berty, her espoused husband,
And has your good starrs in your Pilgrimage,
Brought you amongst you Friends?

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.l: The Lady Katherine, what the Suffolks Dutches,
My quondam Loue, haild through the streets with cords,
And for the murther of a man that liues,
Oh tis vncivill vsage, my good Lady,
Yar villaines all vnto our Soveraigntie,
How dare you thus abuse her royall birth.

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: Pardon my Lord, we did not know her state.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.l: Her heavenly face, then which theres none more faire,
In England, or the World,
Might without other witnesse of her state,
Suffice to tell you, she was nobly borne,
This is that Dutches, mirror of this age,
Shee whom the lordly Bishops of the Realme,
Bonner, and Gardner, persecute so much,
Pardon me Madam, that I haue so long,
Suffered your excellence to stay in bonds.

sp.speaker: Dutc.
sp.l: This your acknowledgment, most mighty king,
Amazeth me, considering my distresse,
For tis a common custome in the world,
To take no notice of the miserable.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.l: I stand amaz'd at this strange accident,
The circumstance whereof weele heare elsewhere,
Meane time thrice welcome to the Polands king,
And much it greeues me that so great a Princes,
Should be so basely handled in my land.

sp.speaker: Sand.
sp.l: Oh helpe deere Lord, and shield vs from our foes,
We are pursued by Brunswicke, and his Captaines,
Who seeke our liues, we flie to your protection.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.l: Whence are you friends.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: The truest friends we haue,
Of England mighty Prince, I know them both,
The first is Doctor Sands, a worthy man,
The other Cranwell, and my Secretary.

div.stage: Enter Brunswicke, English Captaines, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: My Lord of Erbaigh, and the king of Poland,
Shield not those traytors, both to heaven and men,
From the due punishment of their offence,
Behold an Englishman, & a Commander of a good esteeme,
Has his commission signed to apprehend,
This Sands, and Cranwell, fled to you for helpe,
Then as you tender the priviledge of Princes,
Ore their subiects,
Suffer this writ to haue his current heere,
As I haue done through all my territories.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: It ill beseemes the noble duke of Brunswicke,
To be a persecutor of good men.

sp.speaker: Dutch
sp.l: Or you good Captaine, agent in this cause.

sp.speaker: 1. Cap.
sp.l: Thats recreant Berty, and the Suffolks Dutches,
They likewise are included in this scroule.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: My Lord of Poland, we demand them all,
Then yeeld them royall sir, vnto our hands.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.l: First will I sacrifice ten thousand liues,
Ere suffer these religious soules to dye,
My Lord of Brunswicke, you are over bould,
To make so rash an entrance in my land,
Without our speciall licence granted first.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: The league betwixt vs warrants my approach.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.l: The League, for this time, is your priveledge,
But as you dread the Palsgraues puisance
And feare to violate our wrighten loue,
Immediately vntred your forward steps,
Forsake the soyle where you haue set your foote,
Or looke to be withstood with fire and sword,
These Lambes are fled into our foulds for ayd,
And weele defend them, say what may be sayd.

sp.speaker: Bruns.
sp.l: This disobedience drawes vpon your land,
Deserved malediction from the Church.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.l: That weele dispence withall, and to let you know,
How we doe slight those stinglesse menaces,
Heere I create this noble Gentleman,
Earle of Crozam, an Earledome vnder vs,
Religious Docter Sands, our Chapleine,
And M. Cranwell our chiefe Secretary,
So tell Lord Bonner, Gardner, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Atkin.
sp.l: Health and long life vnto the King of Poland,
Captaine, from Englands queene, I thus salute you,
Heere is a countermand for your Commission,
By which you are inioyned to stay the search,
After the Suffolke Dutches, and her friends.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.l: To stay the search? is our dread Soveraigne,
Altered in her Religion, or is she dead:

sp.speaker: Atkin.
sp.l: Shee's dead good sir, Queene Mary is deceas't,
And the most vertuous Lady Elizabeth,
Invested in the regall dignity,
My Soveraigne hearing, that the Lady Katherine,
The Suffolke Dutches, her allie in blood,
Did liue obscurely in these Provinces,
In want, in misery, and great distresse,
Sends to repeale both her, and all her friends,
If such a Lady harbor in your land,
I doe intreate her highnesse Proclamation,
May haue his currant course through every towne.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.l: In you deere sir the Proclamation ends,
Heere is the Dutches, here are all her friends.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I kindly thanke you, for your worthy paines,
Hath the director of all humane liues,
Preserv'd my Soveraigne, that heroicke Maide,
From the intangling snares of blood and death,
And chang'd her prison, to a royall Throne?
Heere on this ground, where first I heard the newes,
I render thanks vnto the gratious heavens,
Thou that send'st Balme of comfort to the wounded,
Ioy to the brused heart, opprest for truth,
Lengthen her dayes as long as heaven hath starres,
Or this faire frame foundation for a world,
Or if it be thy gratious prouidence,
For to remooue her to a happier place,
Let in her stead arise, and from her ashes come,
A Phenix may enlighten Christendome,
Oh, had I now my Children lately lost,
I should surviue as I had neere bin crost.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: That comfort Madam on my bended knee,
Your servant Fox humbly presents your grace.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: My Peregrine, my Susan, then for care
To make a mixture with this too much Ioy,
Or I shall surfet with the raretie.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: Iustice my Lord, Iustice, Fox hath broke my necke.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.l: How comes it Fox, that he exclaimes on thee?

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Marry andt please your Maiestie, twas thus,
This villanous rascall, followed to surprize my Lady,
And being afraid to venter himselfe, set on one of the
Palsegraues Captaines to doe it, whilst he climb'd
Vp into a tree and stood laughing, now sir, I cut the bow,
And he fell downe, and if you haue not broake your necke,
I would you had.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.l: If this be true, he has bought his pleasure deere,
Sirra begon, this justice I allow,
For his derision then, deride him now.

sp.speaker: Clu.
sp.l: All things goes backward for our good,
Madam farewell, your punishment is past,
Now set your mind to punish vs at last.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Revenge shall be a stranger in my heart,
The tortures Ile inflict vpon my foes,
Is kindnesse, for vnkindnesse, grace for death,
For what's prosperity but a puffe of breath,
My Lord of Brunswick, pray let vs be friends.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: With all my heart, since every heart befriends you.

sp.speaker: Pals.
sp.l: It joyes me that your sorrowes heere take end,
wilt please you Madam, heere to stay with vs
Or goe for England, if you so resolue,
Ile see you furnish't with a noble fleete.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: To England with full sailes, blow gentle wind,
I long to see my Soveraigne noble mayd,
Princes I humbly thanke you for these honors,
Done to your handmaide, far vnworthie them,
But time shall testifie my thankefulnesse,
Be smooth rough sea, that I may passe a maine,
To doe my duty to my Soveraigne.

div.stage: Enter Bonner, with officers after him, two Men, and a Woman

sp.l: Downe with him, giue vs leaue to be revenged on him.
For all the tyrany that he hath vs'd

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: What haue I done, you should revile me thus?
What hast thou done to deserue our hate?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Defend me Officers, shall I without Law,
Be trod to death by the rude Multitude.

sp.speaker: 1 Offic.
sp.l: Keepe off my Masters,
Tis her highnesse pleasure,
He shall not be convicted but by Law.
And whether goes he.

sp.speaker: 1. Offi.
sp.l: To the Marshalsea.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We will not leaue him, till we see him in.

div.stage: Enter Keeper, Grindall, Cox, and Scory.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: This is the Prison, heere the Keeper comes,
And with him Master Grindall, Scory, Cox,
Such reverent men as, Bonner, by your meanes,
These many yeeres haue suffered much distresse.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: But now they are deliver'd, and their place,
Bonner, you must an other while supply,
So saies the strict Commission I haue heere.

sp.speaker: Grind.
sp.l: Trust me, I glory not to see his fall.

sp.speaker: Story.
sp.l: Beleeue me, nor doe I.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: Though wee know, had not our Keeper bin more kind to vs.
Then you were M. Bonner, we might here,
Haue starv'd for want of meat, but heaven forgiue you,
We doe with all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Scory.
sp.l: And we will labour too, so much as in vs lies,
Vnto the Councell, you may be favorably
Dealt withall, so fare you well.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Farewell, this course inconstant fortune keepes,
While wan one laughes, an other alwayes weeps.

div.stage: Enter Lord Hunsdon, Admirall, and Clinton.

sp.l: Such measure as to others he hath met,
The same let him receiue, good M. Keeper.
Remember Lollards-tower.
Let his best diet be but from the basket,
Nay, bread and water, is too good for him,
His fat Shroue-tuesday sides may well endure,
A hungry Lent or two, and never hurt him.

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.l: Heere I deliver vp my charge.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: And I receiue him,
Come M. Bonner, you must goe with me

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Stay I haue bethought me, Ile recant.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: It cannot serue your turne.
Recant, he hath already twice or thrice done so.
Tut, he can turne with every weathercock,
Away with him.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Come sir, will you goe.

div.stage: Enter Lord Hunsedon, Admirall and Clinton, with staues, Gentlemen atendants.

sp.speaker: Admi.
sp.l: Who wast that said the Dutches came through Southwark.

sp.speaker: Huns.
sp.l: Twas the Lord Clinton.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: I left her Grace now at S. Georges Church,
Accompanied with M. Richard Berty,
With Doctor Sands, Cranwell, and trustie Fox,
And diverse other Gentlemen attendants.

sp.speaker: Admi.
sp.l: Here at the Martialsea weele stay her comming,
And harke, her trumpets sounds her neere approch,
Lords, Knights, and Gentlemen, I pray you all
By that deere loue you owe her maiestie,
To be officious in the entertayne,
Of this renowned Lady Katherine.
sp.stage: Enter in state, the Dutches, Berty, Sands, Cranwell, and Fox.
sp.l: Cry with in .Heavens preserue your grace,
Your releefe to poore Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: What Prison call you this?

sp.speaker: Cran.
sp.l: The kings-bench Madam, where all these prisoners,
Are detayn'd for debt.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: If they be able to make satisfaction, & will not,
They are worthy to lye there,
But if by cruelty of Creditors,
Tis Christian charity to succour such.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: I haue heard that some lie there in policy,
And haue ingrost into their greedy hands,
The goods of divers thrifty minded men,
And though well able, yet they will not pay.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Great pitty that such men escape vnpunisht,
But are they in the number that doe beg.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: No Madan, they are laid on beds of Downe,
Fare daintely, and never tast of want,
Except it be the want of Liberty,
And that's no want, because they haue large walkes,
As yards, and gardens, and faire bouling-allies,
With company at will to spend the time.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: To them we wish a better Conscence,
But to the poore, and such as want indeed,
One of you giue amongst them 40. Angels,
My troubles make me sensible of theirs:
Distresse is sharpely set, and bites too sore,
To be indur'd by such as are true poore,
So forwards Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: Roome for the Lords.

sp.speaker: Admi.
sp.l: Thrice welcome is the noble Suffolks Dutches,
To vs, and to her royall maiestie,
In whose high favour, you are highly plac't.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: In signe whereof her princely Maiestie,
Restores you to your ancient Siegnories,
Intitles you, as due to you by title,
Barronesse of Willowby, and Earsbie,
Dutches Dowager of Suffolke,
Her highnesse neerest and most deerest subiect.

sp.speaker: Hunsd.
sp.l: Your goods, and lands extracted violently,
Her Maiestie restores to you againe,
Heere's the true inventory of them all,
As they were ceis'd into the Bishops hands.

sp.speaker: Admi.
sp.l: And that you may build on her Princely loue,
It is her pleasure, M. Richard Berty,
The husband of your troubles and your cares,
Should be chiefe Secretary to the State,
Till higher titles doe advance his worth.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: An honor my good Lord Admirall,
That I esteeme, and yet desire it not,
O be it not offensiue to her Grace,
That I haue leaue to leade a private life,
After my painefull travell in strange Lands.

sp.speaker: Adm.
sp.l: Enioy your minds contentment with your mind.

sp.speaker: Hun.
sp.l: You, Doctor Sands, her highnesse, and the Clergie,
Doe consecrate Archbishop of Yorke.

sp.speaker: Sands.
sp.l: An honor far exceeding my desert.

sp.speaker: Clint.
sp.l: Master Cranwell Gentleman vsher to her grace,
Her highnesse will retayne in selfe same place,
To attend her Maiestie.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: With all my heart, I humblie tender a true subiects
Yet might it please her royall Maiestie,
Since I haue serv'd my Lady in distresse,
Indur'd so many troubles for her sake
That I may liue, and dye in serving her.

sp.speaker: Clint.
sp.l: A vertuous inclination, hold it still,
It will renowne thee more then to be great.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: My Lord of Hunsdon, Clinton, Effingam,
I humbly thanke her Maiestie, and you,
Oh may I liue to expresse a loving heart,
By some good action pleasing to you all.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Madam be good vnto a company of poore Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: What other Prison Cranwell call you this.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: This is the Prison of the Marshalsea,
Chiefely pretended for her Highnesse household,
But there are divers other prisoners.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Tis charity to helpe distressed men,
Of what estate so ere, cause they be men,
I leaue their faults respect vnto the Law,
Giue them as much as the'ther Prisones,
But what is he that with a downecast looke,
Giues signes of discontentment.

sp.speaker: Gos.
sp.l: Madam I am a Prisoner heere,
But ioy to see your Grace at liberty.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: That face and voyce, I oft haue seene and heard,
Did not you sometime make abode in Lee.

sp.speaker: Gos.
sp.l: Madam I did, and those that knew mee cald mee Goseling.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Then I am sure, you knew one Mistris White,
This is the man that helpt me to escape,
When we were neere beset with Bonners traynes.

sp.speaker: Cranw.
sp.l: It is my kinseman Madam, now I know him,
What cause hath brought thee to this hard distresse.

sp.speaker: Gos
sp.l: The cause even now aleaged.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Hath Bonner bin so cruell to my friend,
Before mine eyelids weare the seale of sleepe,
If heaven be pleas'd I will release thee Goseling.
And pay thy charges to the vtmost farthing,
Oh my deere friend, it never shall be said
I was vngratefull, where I was befriended,
And now his troubles make me call to mind,
The faithfull dealing of my servant Fox,
See Lords, a man whom I dismist my service,
More through selfe-will, then any iust offence,
Yet hath he quitted that disgrace so well,
That I admire the strangenesse of his art,
For Bonner vs'd him as a speciall meanes,
To seeke my life, which oftentimes he sav'd,
Paying my great vnkindnesse, with kind loue,
Many such servants may this land afford,
That vse their wits to such good purposes,
Heere as a part of thy deserv'd reward,
I freely giue thee a hundred pounds a yeere,
And when I dye my land shall make it good.

sp.speaker: Fox.
sp.l: And when Fox failes you, let him dye in a ditch.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Gramercies gentle servant, now my Lords,
Lets bend our pace towards famous London-Bridge,
How pleasing is the prospect of the City,
Now I haue bin fiue yeares a stranger heere,
Thorow the same to White-hall to her grace,
That I may see my loving Soveraignes face.
